page.title: 2.8.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will investigate different ways to find the solution set to an inequality—by reasoning about the quantities and relationships in context; by guessing some values, substituting them into the inequality, and checking them to see if you make the inequality true; and by first solving a related equation in one variable.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Graph the solution to an inequality in one variable.
  • Solve one-variable inequalities.
  • Interpret the solutions to one-variable inequalities in terms of the situation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 2.8.1: Writing Solutions to Inequalities
  • 2.8.2: Graphing Inequalities
  • 2.8.2: Self Check
  • 2.8.3: Understanding the Meaning of an Inequality
  • 2.8.3: Self Check
  • 2.8.4: Making Sense of Inequalities and Their Solutions (Optional)
  • 2.8.5: Comparing Equality and Inequality
  • 2.8.5: Self Check
  • 2.8.6: Using Technology to Visualize Inequality Solutions (Optional)
  • 2.8.7: Identifying Inequality Solutions on a Graph

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 2.8.8: Practice
  • 2.8.9: Summary

page.title: 2.8.1: Writing Solutions to Inequalities
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

  1. Write some solutions to the inequality \( y ≤ 9.2 \). Be prepared to explain what makes a value a solution to this inequality.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer to the sample responses:

\(9.2\), \(8\), \(4.5\), \(-7\)



  1. Write one solution to the inequality \(7(3 − x) > 14\). Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer to the sample responses:

\(0.5\), \(0\), \(-1\), \(-6\)

page.title: 2.8.2: Graphing Inequalities
page.contents:
Activity

Work with a partner to match each of the following inequalities to its correct number line.

1. \( x < 2 \)                                                   A.

2. \( x ≤ 2 \)                                                   B.  

3. \( x > 2 \)                                                   C.  

4. \( x ≥ 2 \)                                                   D.  

Enter your answer here:

  1. B
  2. D
  3. C
  4. A

page.title: 2.8.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which number line is represented by the inequality \(\;x\;\geq\;–4\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again in a different way: The symbol \(≥\) is represented by a closed circle. The answer is
That’s correct! Check yourself: There is a closed circle on \(-4\). The number line to the right of \(-4\) is highlighted.
Incorrect. Let’s try again in a different way: The number line to the right should be highlighted instead of the left. The answer is
Incorrect. Let’s try again in a different way: The symbol \(≥\) is represented by a closed circle. The number line to the right should be highlighted instead of the left. The answer is

page.title: 2.8.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Graphing Linear Inequalities


What number would make the inequality \(x > 3\) true? Are you thinking, “\(x\) could be 4”? That’s correct, but \(x\) could be 6, too, or 37, or even 3.001. Any number greater than 3 is a solution to the inequality \(x > 3\). We show all the solutions to the inequality \(x > 3\) on the number line by shading in all the numbers to the right of 3, to show that all numbers greater than 3 are solutions. Because the number 3 itself is not a solution, we put an open circle at 3.

We can also represent inequalities using interval notation. There is no upper end to the solution to this inequality. In interval notation, we express \(x > 3\) as \((3, ∞)\). The symbol ∞ is read as “infinity.” It is not an actual number. The figure below shows both the number line and the interval notation.

                                                                        \(x > 3\)

                                                                       \((3, ∞)\)

We use the left parenthesis symbol, (, to show that the endpoint of the inequality is not included. The left bracket symbol, \( [ \), shows that the endpoint is included.
 
The inequality \( x ≤ 1 \) means all numbers less than or equal to 1. Here, we need to show that 1 is a solution, too. We do that by putting a bracket at \( x = 1 \). We then shade in all the numbers to the left of 1, to show that all numbers less than 1 are solutions. See the figure below.

                                                   \( x ≤ 1 \)

                                                   \((-∞,1]\)

There is no lower end to those numbers. We write \(x ≤ 1 \) in interval notation as \( (−∞,1] \). The symbol −\( ∞ \) is read as “negative infinity.” The figure below shows both the number line and interval notation.

 

Inequalities, Number Lines, and Interval Notation

Try It: Graphing Linear Inequalities


Graph the following inequalities and write in interval notation.

\( x > -3 \)
\( x ≤ 5 \)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to graph each inequality and write it in interval notation:

  1. \((-3, ∞]\); 

  2. \((∞, 5]\);

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.8.3: Understanding the Meaning of an Inequality
page.contents:
Activity

A teacher is choosing between two options for a class field trip to an orchard. At each orchard, the same price applies to both chaperones and students.

  • At Orchard A, admission costs $9 per person, and 3 chaperones are required.
  • At Orchard B, the cost is $10 per person, but only 1 chaperone is required.

  1. Which orchard would be cheaper to visit if the class has:
    1. 8 students?
    2. 12 students?
    3. 30 students?

Enter your answer here:

Check your answers:

  1. Orchard B
  2. Orchard B
  3. Orchard A


  1. To help her compare the cost of her two options, the teacher first writes the equation \( 9(n + 3) = 10(n + 1) \), and then she writes the inequality \( 9(n + 3) < 10(n + 1) \).
    1. What does \(n\) represent in each statement?
    2. In this situation, what does the equation \( 9(n + 3) = 10(n + 1) \) mean?
    3. What does the solution to the inequality \( 9(n + 3) < 10(n + 1) \) tell us?
    4. The teacher needs a visual aid to show the school budgeting committee. Graph the solution set to the inequality on the number line. Be prepared to show or explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Check your answers:

  1. \( n \) represents the number of students on the field trip.
  2. \( 9(n + 3) \) is the cost of going to Orchard A, and \( 10(n + 1) \) is the cost of going to Orchard B. The equation represents the two options costing the same amount.
  3. The solution represents the number of students on the field trip at which it would be cheaper to visit Orchard A.
  4. \( n>17 \)


Video: Understanding the Meaning of an Inequality 

Watch the following video to learn more about the meaning of an inequality.

page.title: 2.8.5: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Comparing Equality and Inequality

We can use related equations to help find solutions to inequalities.

Example 

Look at the inequality: 

\( -\frac{3x+7}4<-3x+5\)

We can solve its related equation \(-\frac{3x+7}4=-3x+5\).

After solving, we know that \( x = 3 \).

Does 3 satisfy the inequality?

\( -\frac{3x+7}4<-3x+5\)

\(-\frac{3(3)+7}4\;\begin{array}{l}?\\<\end{array}-3(3)+5\)

\(-4\) \(\not<\) \(-4\)

So, 3 is not a solution.

Let’s try a number bigger than 3, such as 5.

\( -\frac{3x+7}4<-3x+5\)

\(-\frac{3(5)+7}4\;\begin{array}{l}?\\<\end{array}-3(5)+5\)

\(-\frac{11}2\) \(\not<\) \(-10\)

So, 5 is not a solution

Let’s try a number smaller than 3, such as 0.

\( -\frac{3x+7}4<-3x+5\)

\(-\frac{3(0)+7}4\;\begin{array}{l}?\\<\end{array}-3(0)+5\)

\(-\frac74<5\)

So, 0 is a solution.

This means that the solution set is \( x < 3 \).

Try It: Comparing Equality and Inequality


Use the related equation to \(\frac{5x-3}2\;<\;3x\;-\;4\) to find the solution set to the inequality.

  1. What is the related equation?
  2. What is the solution to the related equation?
  3. What values did you test on the inequality?
  4. What is the solution set to the inequality?

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to find the solution set:

  1. \( \frac{5x-3}{2} =3x-4 \)
  2. \( x = 5 \)
  3. Since 5 is the solution to the related equation, I tested it. I also tested 4 and 6 since they represent a value less than and greater than 5.
  4. \( x ≤ 5 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!>

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.8.6: Using Technology to Visualize Inequality Solutions (Optional)
page.contents:
Activity


Consider the inequality \( -\frac12 x + 6 < 4x−3 \). Let’s look at another way to find its solutions.

  1. Use graphing technology to graph \( y=-\frac12 x + 6 \) and \( y=4x-3 \) on the same coordinate plane.

Select the Solution button to check your work.

Sample graph:


  1. Use your graphs to answer the following questions:
    1. >Find the values of \( -\frac {1}{2}x+6 \) and \( 4x-3 \) when \( x \) is 1.
    2. What value of \( x \) makes \( -\frac {1}{2}x+6 \)> and \( 4x-3 \) equal?
    3. For what values of \( x \) is \( - \frac12 x + 6 \) less than \( 4x−3 \)?
    4. For what values of \( x \) is \( - \frac12 x + 6 \) greater than \( 4x−3 \)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

  1. When \( x \) is 1, the value of \( - \frac{1}{2} x+6 \) is \( 5 \frac{1}{2} \), and the value of \( 4x-3 \) is 1.
  2. When \( x \) is equal to 2, the value of \( - \frac{1}{2} x+6 \) is equal to that of \( 4x-2 \).
  3. When \( x \) is greater than 2, the value of \( - \frac{1}{2} x+6 \) is less than that of \(4x-3\).
  4. When \( x \) is less than 2, the value of \( - \frac{1}{2} x+6 \) is greater than that of \( 4x-3 \).


  1. What is the solution to the inequality \( - \frac12 x+ 6 < 4x−3 \)? Be prepared to explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

\( x >2 \)

page.title: 2.8.9: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
• In this lesson, you learned how to:
  • Graph the solution to an inequality in one variable.
  • Solve one-variable inequalities.
  • Interpret the solutions to one-variable inequalities in terms of the situation.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 2.8.1: Writing Solutions to Inequalities
    • In this activity, you activated what you know about the solutions to an inequality and ways to find the solutions. For the first time, you referred to the solutions as the solution set of the inequality.
  • 2.8.2: Graphing Inequalities
    • In this activity, you learned how to graph an inequality on a number line. You learned how to represent an inequality using set notation. You know that an open circle is used to represent \(<\) and \(>\), while a closed circle represents \(≤\) and \(≥\).
  • 2.8.3: Understanding the Meaning of an Inequality
    • In this activity, you interpreted an inequality and its solution set in terms of a situation. Adding context can help you intuit why the solutions to an inequality are often represented by a ray on the number line. The activity also prompted you to think about the solutions to an inequality in terms of a related equation.
  • 2.8.3: Self Check
  • 2.8.4: Making Sense of Inequalities and Their Solutions (Optional)
    • In this optional activity, you received another opportunity to make sense of inequalities and their solutions in context. The context helped reinforce why it makes sense for the solutions to an inequality to be represented by a set of points on one side of a particular value on the number line.
  • 2.8.5: Comparing Equality and Inequality
    • In this activity, you further developed the idea that we can solve an inequality by first solving a related equation. Previously, you reasoned about the solutions to an inequality in context. Here, you transitioned to solving an inequality without a context.
  • 2.8.5: Self Check
  • 2.8.6: Using Technology to Visualize Inequality Solutions (Optional)
    • In this optional activity, you visualized an inequality in one variable in another way: by graphing the expressions on each side and comparing the values of the expressions at different values of the variable. This allows you to see the values at which the inequality is satisfied.
  • 2.8.7: Identifying Inequality Solutions on a Graph
    • In this activity, you identified a graph that correctly showed the solution to an inequality.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 2.8.8: Practice

Checking In 

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.

page.title: 2.8.3: Self Check
page.contents:
A water park charges $17 per entry plus a $40 fee for raft rentals. An amusement park charges a $21 entry fee.

For the number of entries, \(e\), which inequality represents the total cost of the water park being less than the total cost of the amusement park?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again in a different way: Should the fee be added or subtracted? The answer is \(17e\;+\;40\;<\;21e \).

That’s correct! Check yourself: The water park is represented by \( 17e\;+\;40 \) and the amusement park by \( 21e \). In this inequality, the water park is less than the total cost of the amusement park.
Incorrect. Let’s try again in a different way: The $40 fee applies to the water park, not the amusement park. The answer is \( 17e\;+\;40\;<\;21e \).
Incorrect. Let’s try again in a different way: This represents the total cost of the water park being greater than the total cost of the amusement park. The answer is \( 17e\;+\;40\;<\;21e \).

page.title: 2.8.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Translating Situations into Inequalities

Many real-life situations require us to use inequalities. Translating the details of these situations into inequalities is the first step in understanding them. Let’s look at how we can translate these situations into mathematical sentences.

Example #1 

Imani won a mini-grant of $4,000 to buy tablet computers for her classroom. The tablets she would like to buy cost $254.12 each, including tax and delivery. She can only spend up to the amount of the mini-grant.

Choose a variable to represent the quantity of tablet computers:

Let \( n \) = the number of tablets.

Translate: Write a sentence that gives the information provided.

$254.12 times the number of tablets is no more than $4,000.

Translate into an inequality:

\( 254.12n < 4000 \)

Imani’s situation is represented by the inequality \(254.12n < 4000\).

Example #2 

Taleisha’s phone plan costs her $28.80 a month plus $0.20 per text message. Her monthly bill can be no more than $50.

Choose a variable to represent the quantity of text messages:

Let \( t \) = the number of text messages.

Translate: Write a sentence that gives the information provided.

$28.80 plus $0.20 times the number of text messages is less than or equal to $50.

Translate into an inequality:

\( 28.80 + 0.20t < 50 \)

Taleisha’s situation is represented by the inequality \( 28.80 + 0.20t < 50 \).

Try It: Translating Situations into Inequalities

Read each problem below and write an inequality to represent the situation.


  1. Angie has at most $20 to spend on juice boxes for her son’s preschool picnic. Each pack of juice boxes costs $2.63. She will also buy one bag of chips for $3.99. 
  2. Jose wants to surprise his girlfriend with a birthday party at her favorite restaurant. It will cost $42.75 per person for dinner, including tip and tax. He must also pay $5 for parking. His budget for the party is less than $500. 

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to write an inequality for each situation:

  1. \( 2.63j + 3.99 ≤ 20 \)
  2. \( 42.75p + 5 < 500 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.8.5: Comparing Equality and Inequality
page.contents:
Activity


  1. Solve this equation and check your solution: \( -\frac{4(x+3)}5 = 4x-12 \).

Enter your answer here:

\( x=2 \)


  1. Consider the inequality: \( -\frac{4(x+3)}5 \le 4x-12 \).
    1. Choose a couple of values less than 2 for \( x \). Are they solutions to the inequality?
    2. Choose a couple of values greater than 2 for \( x \). Are they solutions to the inequality?
    3. Choose 2 for \( x \). Is it a solution?
    4. Graph the solution to the inequality on the number line.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers. Values chosen vary.
  1. Values less than 2 are not solutions.
  2. Values greater than 2 are solutions.
  3. Yes, 2 is a solution.


Are you ready for more?

Extending Your Thinking

Here is a different type of inequality: \(x^2\leq4\).

  1. Is 1 a solution to the inequality? Is 3 a solution? How about \(-3\)?
  2. Describe all solutions to this inequality. (If you like, you can graph the solutions on a number line.)
  3. Describe all solutions to the inequality \(x^2\geq9\). Test several numbers to make sure your answer is correct.

Enter your answers here:

Check your answers:

  1. yes, no, no.
  2. \( -2 ≤ x ≤ 2 \)
  3. \( x ≤-3 \) or \( x ≥ 3 \)

page.title: 2.8.5: Self Check
page.contents:
Which number line represents the solution to the inequality?

\(\frac12(–2z\;+\;2)\;\geq\;12\)

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: What does the open circle mean? The value \(-11\) is also a solution. The answer has a closed circle on the point \(-11\) with the number line to the left shaded.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The value \(-10\) is not a solution. The answer has a closed circle on the point \(-11\) with the number line to the left shaded.
That’s correct! Check yourself: The solution is \( z ≤ -11 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check your operations when solving the related equation for \( z \). The answer has a closed circle on the point \(-11\) with the number line to the left shaded.

page.title: 2.8.7: Identifying Inequality Solutions on a Graph
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Which graph correctly shows the solution to the inequality \( \dfrac{7x-3}9 \geq 8-2x \)? Show or explain your reasoning.

A

B

C

D

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer and compare your reasoning to the sample responses:

Graph C. Sample responses:

  • I tested 2, 3, and 4 for the values of \(x\), and 3 and 4 make the inequality true.
  • I solved a related equation and then tested a couple of values on either side of the solution.

page.title: 2.8.8: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

1. Here is an inequality: \(\frac{7x+6}2\leq3x+2\)
Select all of the values that are a solution to the inequality.

Correct! \(x = -3\), \(x = -2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.8.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are \(x = -3\), \(x = -2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. Which number line is represented by the inequality \( x ≤ 6 \)?

  1.  
  2.  
  3.   
  4.   

Correct! 

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.8.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 3–4, use the following information:

Scooter rental company A charges $9 per hour plus an $11 initiation fee. Scooter rental company B charges $15 per hour.


3. A customer writes the following inequality to represent the situation: \(9h + 11 > 15h\).

Which of the following is true about the given inequality?

Correct! Company A costs more than Company B.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.8.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Company A costs more than Company B. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4. For which number of hours does Company B cost less?

Correct! 1 hour

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.8.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 1 hour. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 5–7, use the following information:

Cycle Rentals offers 20 membership points for each day that a customer rents a bike. Bikes Unlimited offers 5 membership points for each day that a customer rents a bike plus 60 points for joining the membership club.


5. The equation \(20x = 5x + 60\) represents a possible constraint about the situation. Solve for \(x\). Enter only integers.

\(x\) = ____

Correct! The correct answer is 4. If you rent a bike for longer than 4 days, you earn more membership points at Cycle Rentals.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.8.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 4. If you rent a bike for longer than 4 days, you earn more membership points at Cycle Rentals. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

6. Which shop offers more membership points if you rent a bike for longer than the constraint you found in the previous question?

Correct! Cycle Rentals

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.8.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Cycle Rentals. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

7. Which number line represents the solution to the inequality, \(20x > 5x + 60\), representing the situation when you earn more membership points at Cycle Rentals?

Correct! 

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.8.2 and 2.8.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

8. Which number line represents the solution to \(5+8x<3(2x+4)\)?

Correct! 

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.8.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

9. Find the solution set to this inequality by solving the related equation: \(2x-3>\frac{2x-5}2\)

Correct! \(x<\frac12\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.8.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x<\frac12\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

10. Here is an inequality: \(\frac{-10+x}4+5\geq\frac{7x-5}3\). What value of \(x\) will produce equality (or make the two sides equal)? Enter only integers.

\(x\) = ____

Correct! 2

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.8.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 2. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 2.8.4: Making Sense of Inequalities and Their Solutions (Optional)
page.contents:
Activity

To help pay for his tuition, a college student plans to work in the evenings and on weekends. He has been offered two part-time jobs: working in the guest-services department at a hotel and waiting tables at a popular restaurant.

  • The job at the hotel pays $18 an hour and offers $33 in transportation allowance per month.
  • The job at the restaurant pays $7.50 an hour plus tips. The entire wait staff typically collects about $50 in tips each hour. Tips are divided equally among the 4 wait staff members who share a shift.

  1. The equation \( 7.50h + \frac {50}{4}h = 18h + 33 \) represents a possible constraint about a situation.
    1. Solve the equation and check your solution.
    2. Here is a graph on a number line.

      Put a scale on the number line so that the point marked with a circle represents the solution to the equation.

Enter your answer here:

Check your answers:

  1. \( h=16.5 \)
  2. Sample response

  1. Does one job pay better if:
    1. The student works fewer hours than the solution you found earlier? If so, which job?
    2. The student works more hours than the solution you found earlier? If so, which job?

Be prepared to explain or show how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Check your answers:

  1. Yes. The hotel job pays better if he works fewer than 16.5 hours a month. Sample reasoning: I found the pay for both jobs using numbers that are less than 16.5 and found that pay at the hotel is always higher.
  2. Yes. The restaurant job pays better if he works more than 16.5 hours a month. Sample reasoning: I found the pay for both jobs using numbers that are greater than 16.5 and found that pay at the restaurant is always higher.

  1. Here are two inequalities and two graphs that represent the solutions to the inequalities.

    • Inequality 1: \( 7.50h + \frac {50}{4}h < 18h + 33 \)
    • Inequality 2: \( 7.50h + \frac {50}{4}h > 18h + 33 \)

    A

    B

    1. Put the same scale on each number line so that the circle represents the number of hours that you found earlier.
    2. Match each inequality with a graph that shows its solution. Be prepared to explain or show how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here are some sample responses to compare your answers.

  • A  

  • B  

  • Graph B shows the solution to Inequality 1, and Graph A shows the solution to Inequality 2. Sample explanations:

    • Inequality 1 shows the pay at the hotel \( (18h+33) \) being greater than the pay at the restaurant \( 7.50h+ \frac{50}{4} \). Earlier, we found out that the hotel job is better when the student works less than 16.5 hours. Graph B shows \( h<16.5 \). This means Graph B shows the solution to Inequality 1.
    • If we substitute a value greater than 16.5 for \( h \), we have a true statement for Inequality 2 and a false statement for Inequality 1. This means \( h>16.5 \) is a solution to Inequality 2 but not to Inequality 1. 
    • If we substitute a value less than 16.5 for \( h \), we have a true statement for Inequality 1 but not for Inequality 2. So \( h<16.5 \) is a solution to Inequality 1.
